awd_titl_txt: RAPID Collaborative Research: Do mangroves provide better coastal protection than salt marshes? A Hurricane Harvey case study from Port Aransas, Texas, USA
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal marshes provide critical ecosystem services, including erosion prevention and shoreline protection from storm surges that often result when hurricanes make landfall. For several years, vegetation in coastal wetlands has been shifting from grasses and forbs to taller, woody mangroves, raising concerns about the impact these changes may have on these important ecosystem services. Over the past several years, scientists have been conducting a large mangrove removal experiment to study the ecological consequences of mangrove expansion near Port Aransas, Texas. Hurricane Harvey made landfall near this experiment, providing an unprecedented opportunity to study the immediate impacts of mangrove expansion on shoreline protection and other vital ecosystem services.  This RAPID award will allow scientists to gain knowledge on the role of coastal wetlands that will be extremely valuable to coastal managers responsible for restoration and management projects along shorelines vulnerable to future hurricanes.

This research will provide a critical understanding of the impact of mangrove expansion on the role of coastal wetlands in the provision of critical ecosystem services in response to intense storms. Hurricane Harvey provides a unique opportunity to answer a critical question - do mangroves provide fundamentally different shoreline protection than the low stature grasses and forbs they replace?  The researchers conducting this study are using a pre-existing mangrove removal experiment that was in the path of the hurricane to test the hypothesis that large woody plants like mangroves are better able to resist these large storms, and therefore provide improved shoreline protection. This work will also provide a better conceptual understanding to the role of biotic factors in regulating the impact of large storms. This information is of critical importance to land managers responsible for restoring the ecosystem services coastal wetlands can provide.

por.por_cntn:
Coastal wetlands provide many valuable and essential ecosystem services, including the provision of food, cultural and recreational opportunities, and shoreline protection. The 2017 landfall of Hurricane Harvey on the central Texas coast tested the capacity of wetlands to protect and stabilize shorelines, thus reducing erosion and protecting natural and built communities on higher ground. This project demonstrated that the types of plants present may influence the capacity of wetlands to alleviate storm effects. In particular, marshes, dominated by low-stature grass and forb species, and mangroves - taller, more rigid trees and shrubs, provided different shoreline protection.

 

Hurricane Harvey made landfall near a set of existing mangrove and marsh study sites as a category 4 storm in August 2017, providing an ideal opportunity to test how vegetation type influences shoreline protection. The overarching project goal was to determine if mangrove or marsh vegetation provides better shoreline protection. The research team conducted a series of measurements to compare 1) plant cover, 2) erosion and debris accumulation, and 3) soil characteristics and accretion. Key findings include: 1) Mangroves were more vulnerable than marsh vegetation to hurricane damage and loss. At the study site closest to the eye of the storm, mangrove cover decreased by 25% or more, though many damaged plants showed signs of regrowth. There was no detectable decrease in marsh plant cover. 2) Near the storm's eye, shoreline erosion was highest where mangrove cover was less than 30%. There was no detectable shoreline erosion at sites further from the storm's direct path. A similar amount of debris accumulated in both mangrove and marsh vegetation. 3) Soil accretion rates increased during the storm, but were relatively modest compared to other hurricane deposition events. Sulfide concentrations in the soil - an indicator of plant stress - were high for > 1 year after the storm, and may have contributed to a decline in root biomass of both marsh and mangrove plants. This persistent hurricane effect on wetland plants may reduce ecosystem resilience following future storms or other disturbance events.

 

This work documented that mangroves were more vulnerable to hurricane damage than marsh plants, but that mangroves were better at protecting the shoreline from erosion. The hurricane had lasting belowground impacts on both plant types. Overall, ongoing mangrove expansion along the Gulf Coast will likely improve coastal protection from occasional severe storms.

 

Products from this work include presentations at ten regional and international scientific conferences and two peer-reviewed publications. Broader impacts included training of two undergraduate interns, three technicians, and two graduate students. In addition, the investigators participated in cross-institutional workshops on ecosystem responses to hurricanes to disseminate their results to stakeholders and managers.
